subject: CBS News Sunday Morning: None-too-sweet revelation about our food
body:
CBSNews.com












  Home | U.S. | World | Politics | SciTech | Health | Entertainment | Business | Opinion | Sports | Blogs | Interactives | Video 

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday Morning | Face The Nation 






June 15, 2007
How 
      sweet it is! 
It’s 
      a lot more than a familiar expression. You’d be surprised to learn just 
      how much sugar shows up in all kinds of things we eat. In fact, you’d 
      be so surprised 
      that, this Sunday Morning, our Susan Spencer 
      tells you all about the sugar in our foods, in our Cover 
      Story.
After 
      which we have a study in black and white: Silhouettes are an age-old style 
      of portraiture. We’ll tell you all about where they came from, and show you some, well, 
      cutting-edge examples!

On 
      this Father’s Day, our Bill Geist has gone out to talk with some dads 
      whose children chose to follow in their footsteps, and that includes Bill’s own son, 
      Willie, who can also be seen on 
      television; you’ll have to 
      watch Sunday to find out just where.

Father’s Day is also the 
      perfect time for a close-up look at the father of our nation – George 
      Washington. Joie Chen clears up all our misconceptions about our first 
      president. This is your chance to find out if he really did have wooden dentures!

Bob 
      Seger is one of rock music’s golden oldies,one of the greats from the 
      1970s. Is he still the 
      same? With Russ Mitchell, we’ll make 
      inquiries.

After which we move 
      on to dessert and, since June is the month for weddings, we’re going 
      to introduce you to a baker whose work truly takes the cake. Sylvia 
      Weinstock’s wedding cakes costs thousands (sometimes, tens of thousands) 
      of dollars.  This weekend, she shares her recipe for success. Oh, and 
      you won’t believe her frosting!

Our 
      plate is full… this Sunday 
      Morning. Listen for our trumpet!
